etymologies: late 16th century: from French épithète, or via Latin from Greek epitheton, neuter of epithetos ‘attributed’, from epitithenai ‘add’, from epi ‘upon’ + tithenai ‘to place’

definitions: an adjective or phrase expressing a quality or attribute regarded as characteristic of the person or thing mentioned

examples.text: old men are often unfairly awarded the epithet ‘dirty’

shortDefinitions: adjective or phrase expressing quality or attribute regarded as characteristic of person or thing mentioned

definitions: an epithet used as a term of abuse

examples.text: people jeered and hurled racial epithets

shortDefinitions: such word or phrase as term of abuse
